d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (15:37): on gareth hay's point about making the web better and html5 not doing that, aiui a better web is one that conforms to the w3c standards (largely) this is manifested by people running their site through the w3c validator and proving it's valid, no-one ever links to the actual standard always to the validator
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (15:37): so make a validator that complies with the 'good and proper' recommendations in html5
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (15:38): but is that not correct, no-one ever points to the actual spec to say they are valid, always to the validator results?

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:40): d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631: yeah, people tend to point to the validator. which is why it important to have a conformance checker instead of a mere validator

d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (15:41): well, from my now developing point of view i don't think there's any need for two specs, just one from which a 'good and proper html' conformance checker can be built
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (15:42): HTML5 already has "two specs"
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (15:42): they are just intertwined
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (15:42): see for instance the syntax section
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (15:42): (which actually has two separate sections, not a good example...)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:43): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: we need better marketing of the nature of the spec on this point
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (15:43): cool, i was referring to my suggestion from yesterday that two versions of the html5 spec might help gareth ad tina

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:46): wow, the commenters on that article on The Register just don't seem to grasp the issue
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (15:46): right, now for the dumbass questions, what's the difference between a conformance checker and a validator?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (15:46): register?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:46): see the link I posted above

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:48): d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631: a conformance checker checks for violations of the machine-checkable conformance criteria. a validator checks if the document is valid according to a schema
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:49): d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631: if the schema does not capture all the machine-checkable conformance criteria, there is a difference
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:49): d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631: (in practice schemas don't)

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:50): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I like how one of the comments says that MS only implement standards they are involved in creating. There are plenty of standards that they were involved in that they don't implement (either at all, or properly).
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:50): which comment # was that?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:51): 4
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:51): "Tom"
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (15:51): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: that stylesheet is great
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:51): quite of lot of the commentors seem to think it's possible to just write a standards compliant browser overnight.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:52): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: which is why the IETF "consensus *and running code*" is better than mere "consensus"
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:53): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: agreed.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:53): actually, IETF is "*rough* consensus and running code"
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (15:53): the fact that HTML5 has multiple people already implementing the parsing section, and looking over with it with fine-toothcomb, undoubtedly helps
